title: How many influenza positive viruses will FluNet record for Qatar between 13 November 2017 and 19 November 2017 (epidemiological week 46)?
preds: trying a log-linear model (moderately predictive), based on the rising edges of the curves

I was looking for information about the epidemiological week. Found out there are influenza positive and negative viruses. I downloaded the flunet's laboratory surveillance information on Qatar and download the who year's listing on influenza positive viruses. Found out that the latest figure is 116 in week 42 (2017) but there is no clear trend curve in any direction. Then I downloaded previous year's charts and in 2016 in week 46 the number has been 139 and 2015 it was 576 and 2014 it has been 33. So I came up with a resolution that the scope of epidemic is extremely hard to forecast, but I will base my estimation on the fact that 2014 was a massive outbreak. the trend should be decreasing, if there are any lessons learned. In addition Qatar is vaccinating people long before the outbreak. There's an article in FluNet where it is said that there has been vaccinations on healthcare workers. And they have succeeded very well after the outbreak of 2015. That's why I made an edit of decreasing the changes of more than 120 but less than 200. Perhaps that still could be decreased. I hope my reasoning can help you guys as well. Maybe the figures could still be updated later on this week. Every time I edit, does it make a new forecast? just thinking, because isn't the point to update the forecasts?
Shifting a little higher to account for the number of cases in the last few weeks.

As by now recent data is available, I'm basing my forecast on a moving average (4 weeks) and corresponding moving standard deviation. Without knowledge (or even rough idea) of the underlying distribution, I first assume a normal distribution with the estimated parameters, and then adjust for possible outliers, effectively shifting the distribution to higher values (effectively assigning a non-zero probability to the 200-293 category).

Reviewing available history of FluNet data for Quatar (< 3 years):  Last time the number of influenza positive specimens [in a week] exceeded 200 was in 2015.  There was clear antecedent log-phase.  Most recent data is stable to downtrending; at this point even the onset of a new log-phase would be likely to take more than a week to exceed 200 positive specimens per week.

Aggressive vaccination plan plus the blockade which curtails some travel will cut down on the flu cases within the Qatari national and expat white-collar work force.
I 've seen some analysis based on the large expat workforce. I believe there could be an issue in the accurately of reporting influenza cases in a poulation of 2.6 million people 88 to 90 % are an uneducated expat labor mostly from under developed , poor countries. I'm not confident that they would be diagnosed in proportion to the upper and white collar classes in Qatar. If influenza became epidemic in the expat community  then I believe we could see a big spike in reported flu cases however, I don't think we are there yet. How I answer this question "How many positive viruses will FluNet record for Qatari Nationals and white collar expat workers in Qatar between 13 November 2017 and 19 November 2017 ? 
https://www.hrw.org/world-report/2016/country-chapters/qatar
Initially considering a jump from the current available week data of week 42 to 46 based on jumps that occurred in the previous 2 years.

Following @Khalid and @mwokasch comment, I agreed the latest data point is a very good indicator. I also checked for month over month seasonality in the data. It is apparent that the number of flu tends to rise from September to December. So I am adjusting my expectation to be higher than the latest data.
Too hard to predict without much data.

Shaping up to be a rough flu season if Australia is any indication.
http://www.cnn.com/2017/11/08/health/flu-season-vaccine-effectiveness-study/index.html

Based on the observations of @dsarin and @Khalid I'm just spreading across the two most likely categories, as the number can be revised from initial publication. Thus, it all depends on how fast the resolution comes.

Given that it appears the data for a given week can be revised over time, I am somewhat regretting forecasting on this question.  I am replacing my prior, more subjective, forecasts with an ARIMA model auto-fit on all available data for Qatar.
This is weird, because on November 1 the "week 42" total said 63, and now it says 116.  Unless I screwed up somehow.  Anyway, prepare to update when week 43 appears.
I have no idea. Seems like a hard question.

I am not looking at the information. I am looking at the manner in which the information is presented and the underlying logic dissecting the underpinnings of the influenza virological surveillance. 
Very well done systematic logic(Paper): http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/irv.12354/full
Still waiting for Week 43 figures to be published, but the numbers on the website have been increased compared to last week. The average for Weeks 39-42 is now 120.75.
In 2017 week 42, the number is 600, with a strong degree of persistence in numbers in consecutive weeks. There doesn't appear to be a meaningful trend based on previous years.

This is a pure statistical reasoning. I have created a probability matrix by category ("less than 27",...) by week for the period of 2012-2017. Then I have calculated the average of the probability between week 43 and week 49. 
Although recorded in 2015, there might be pattern that once you are above 120 cases, it might lead to higher recordings in the weeks after, which could seem probable since due to the ease of the diseases' transmission more people contaminated with influenza A could lead to more contaminations. At the moment of writing I only see one instance (week 41), but then it stabilises for 2 weeks in a row between 27 and 120.
Reviewing past data for this date range. 2016, with 139, appears to have been an outlier. Adjusting.
I arrived at this from an average of several forecast methods.

Same week last year was 139.
Recent weeks’ data suggests a similar trend.

Previous months going back to 2012 have had a spike in terms of number of infections due to the spread of the virus. It is highly unlikely that less than 27 confirmed cases are during one of the highest points of the season. Thus the probability was put at 2%.  Previous data suggests that the around the 45th week of the year is potential increase in outbreaks, specifically 2013 being the biggest. If we consider 2013 an outlier then data predicts a normal influenza season. If conditions hold with a mild spike occurring around the 45th week then between 27-120 is the most likely outcome.  However past results do not predicate future outcomes. With the rise of super bugs and how previously the influenza vaccine did not cover the most predominant strains in 2013 & 2015. We are on tract for a large spike then normal.  The influenza vaccine does not immunize the host against all forms of the virus but rather forms that are predicted to have the largest impact on the general populace. There is some evidence to suggest given the reports coming from New Zealand and Australia that there is more to fear this year. Britains NHS is gearing up for a bad flu season due to this speculation, However it should be noted that Britain has an aging population compared to Qatar which could lead to higher infection rates there. Hong Kong had a major influenza outbreak over the summer which doctors have likely attributed to mutation of the virus. The previous mild winter flu season is suggested to have contributed to the high outbreaks this year, due to lack of natural immunity. Qatar's health ministry has launched a influenza awareness campaign for vaccination.  Given the large number of foreign workers who travel often the likelihood one contracts influenza is extremely high. Given the lack of herd immunity within the developing country, any outbreak will likely be magnified.  Prediction for X < 27 or less cases is 2%
A prediction for 27 - 120 is placed at 54% is for previous data suggesting a normal season all else equal.
The prediction of 120 < X < 200 is 37% for the higher levels of influenza experienced by neighbouring countries.
A prediction for 200 - 293 is pegged at 7% for the lack of herd immunity, religious festivals,  Note: the 2% and 7% are also hedges against availability biases, and black swans. Sources:

Making my best guess based on the flu chart and weather forecasts for Qatar during that week.

To get a baseline forecast I basically just fit a linear model to the values for Week 46 by the values for Week 42 and applied those coefficients to the current value for week 42 and then used the prior deviation of Week 46 values to assign probabilities to each bin. I then took the lower probability values and prorated them to the other bins. I will update later based on further evidence and analysis. I'll also note, my analysis led me to a conclusion that is conspicuously high. I encourage someone to explain to me what I'm missing on this one, because I think there has to be something.
There is an ongoing vaccination program. It is currently in that 27-100 range. Unlikely to move quickly.

There are substantially more cases at this time of year compared to the previous four. What's the reason? There are some clues - Australia and New Zealand have had a bad year, due to a strain not covered by the annual vaccination, so the Northern Hemisphere is bracing for the worst (even though the vaccination has been reformulated). Although Qatar does not have a cold "winter" as such, the change in weather starting from November does lead to increased respiratory problems, so there could be a seasonal increase in cases.
http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/09/12/nhs-fears-worst-flu-season-history/
https://www.statnews.com/2017/10/16/flu-virus-severity/ How fast can one expect flu to spread? The median "Reproduction Number" of typical seasonal flu is around 1.2-1.4, compared to around 1.8 for pandemics. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4169819/ In a population with zero immunity, one flu case will therefore infect between 1 and 2 more of those that come in contact with it. However, if around 50% of the exposed population is immune, either through vaccination or prior exposure to this particular strain, then the infection is not expected to spread. Most of Qatar's population consists of itinerant expatriate workers, who are unlikely to have been vaccinated this year, and if this is a new strain not many will have been exposed to it before either. The  comings and goings of the workforce means new viruses can come in and spread quickly. Confirmation of the Qatar figures can be seen in this recent report from the UAE, which has similar demographics and environment.
http://gulfnews.com/news/uae/health/influenza-virus-highly-active-in-the-uae-1.1917646 If it becomes generally known that this year's flu will be more severe than usual, more people will visit the doctor whereas in other years they may just rest and recover, so we could expect proportionally more cases to be reported. One will have to watch the numbers week by week - the latest is for Week 42, so there will be another two or three updates before this question's deadline to spot any trend.
[note to self: week 42 is 63.   Prepare to update substantially on basis of week 43.]

Going back to 2012 flu cases in week 46 have been higher than in the prior four weeks, with the exception of 2014. As well, in 2016, 2015, and 2012 rates were significantly higher (around 2-3 times higher) than the prior four week average. With that in mind I am expecting an uptick in cases over the next few weeks in Qatar but definitely going to keep an eye on case numbers over the next few weeks.

Here's a Summary of my work:
Using the data from: http://apps.who.int/flumart/Default?ReportNo=12 I pulled all of the influenza data between Week 1, 2012 through Week 42, 2017. First a few things that didn't work:
1)  Using the prior years to predict current period
2)  Using the rolling year to predict current period
3)  Trend-lining based on current results
4)  8 Week and longer rolling periods to predict results Now the promising results:
1) Most recent data point is the single best indicator of the 4-week forward results 
2) Rolling 2-week period, predicting the 4-week forward results
3) Rolling 4-week period, predicting the 4-week forward results Things that can be done to further improve the results.
1) Cross-sectional results of the former models improved forecasting. 2)  The standard errors of predictions were auto-correlated.  That is, by knowing: 
 -  How much the model was off in recent periods can be added to the current predictions Methodology Results / Data points
Base Predictions (Unadjusted):  
Most Recent =  59.5
2-Week = 61.3
4-Week =  53.1 Cross-Referenced Prediction: 58.8 Historical Auto-correlation of Errors Adjusted Prediction:  71.5 Here's the really nice part of all of this:  71.5 is nearly the exact center of the range provided, and with a standard deviation of errors of just 32.6 means that something catastrophic has to happen to move the prediction outside of this range. On this point, by "Catastrophic" I'm specifically looking at something like 2015 week 43-49 where the model simply did not work.  Again, since the errors are auto-correlated, we should know that the model missed in the weeks ahead. Last note:  The reason for the non-normal distribution around the midpoint (i.e. 0% in the low bracket) is because the un-adjusted model underestimated the prior 9 results, again showing the auto-correlation.   Hope this helps.
Based on historic data, and current trends, it seems the 27-120 is the most likely. By the way, it would be week 46 if you're trying to figure this database.
